div3.head: Rags Wanted.
div3.p: --The highest market price will be paid at this office for all kinds of Cotton and Linnen , in large or small quantities.

At last we have the result of the Yankee elections, after a delay which gave rise to an infinity of conjectures, none of which came near the mark.--Lincoln has carried all the States except two--New Jersey and Kentucky (not Missouri, as we heard the other day). We shall now see whether Seward is right in his prediction that the re-election of Lincoln would bring the whole Confederacy to their praying for re-admission to "Father Abraham's" bosom, to use his own profane and indecent expression.
The attempt of Seward to make his people believe that the Confederacy was deeply interested in the result of the Yankee election corresponds so well with what the Herald and Tribune have been teaching for several months that we cannot refrain from thinking it was dictated from headquarter, and is of a piece with those tremendous paper victories of which the Yankees have gained so many since the commenced.
As far as we are able to judge, the large majority of the people cared nothing in the world about it, one way or the other.
They knew that, let the result be what it might, the matter in which they were at all interested — would be continued all the same.
They, indeed, rather preferred Lincoln, for they had been trying him for four years and knew his calibre exactly.
They had reason to expect more ability from in the conduct of campaigns, and they reasonably have expected less.

to see her the leading politicians of the Yankee States sketch campaigns before they and force results before the issue Seward is here, in the last month of consequences to follow the Lincoln identical with the consequences the Herald, Tribune and Times told us six would follow the march of Grant upon None of the predictions of the newspaper have come true; and if Grant, with three hundred thousand men, could not we are not much afraid that the mere election of Lincoln will.

We published on Saturday the Yankee account of the capture of the Florida in the bay of San Salvador.
From that account, it is clear that the Yankees violated the neutrality of the harbor, for all the but five or six were on shore, which they would not have been had they not considered themselves protected from attack by the neutrality of the harbor.
This capture is, therefore, either a flagrant outrage upon the Emperor of Brazil, or it has been captured at that potentate.
We are both to improve treachery to him, we therefore choose to regard it as an outrage of the Yankees.

When in 1814, a British squadron made an attack, upon and succeeded in capturing, the privateer General Armstrong, in a neutral port, the Government of that day entered a solemn protest against the as not only in itself a violation of international law, but as calculated to do infinite mischief in future by rendering it impossible for any nation to preserve her neutrality when two other nations were at war. The Yankees have published many books about that war, and we will venture to say, in no one of them is a furious tirade against England for this violation of neutrality omitted.
The Government of the United States made a requisition upon the Government to which the violated port belonged for damages to a large amount, and the claim was only settled a few years ago by the Emperor of the French, we think, who was chosen umpire on the occasion.

In this case, as in every other where it has suited their interest or convenience, the Yankees have imitated the English in all those aggressions of which they were wont to complain.
The Declaration of Independence contains a pretty fair catalogue of the offences with which poor old George III, who was crazy half of his life, was charged; and the Yankees, in the days of the Union, used to set the Declaration of Independence above the Constitution simply for the sake of its silly affirmation that all men are created equal.
Now, there is not one sin attributed in the Declaration to George III.
which the Yankees have not been guilty of in a most aggravated form since the separation.
This seizure of the Florida in a neutral port will breed trouble some of these days with the Government of Brazil.

div3.head: Special Notice.--two Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen from my residence, on Governor street, on Thursday, the 10th instant, a large Red Pieded Milch Cow (rather milk and cider color), without ear marks, in full milk.
I will cheerfully pay the above reward to any person finding her and delivering her to me; and if she has been stolen and slaughtered, I will pay one thousand dollars for the apprehension and conviction of the thief.

div3.head: Special Notice.--Old "Gravely" Tobacco.
div3.p: --Just received, a lot of Old "Gravely" Tobacco, pronounced by judges to be the best chew to be found.
Call on T. C. C. Drewry, 173 Main street, next to R. H. Maury & Co.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--Parties can find all the latest news of the election in the North in the Northern Papers, received this (Monday) Morning at the Confederate Reading-Room.
A new arrival, recollect, this morning.--Also, all the latest Southern Papers, city Papers, Yankee Pictorials.
Paper, Envelopes, &c., for writing letters.
Recollect, the Reading-Room is open at night.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--Any information concerning my son, John W. McGEHEE, a prisoner at Point Lookout, company K, Seventh division, Prisoners' camp, and a member of the Fifth Virginia cavalry, will be very thankfully received.
He has been reported dead.

div3.head: Personal.
div3.p:
--Information is desired of William G. Lane, company D, Fourteenth Virginia regiment, who was wounded and taken prisoner at Gettysburg on the 3d day of July, 1863.--It is supposed he is now in some Northern prison.
Any information would be thankfully and gratefully received by his distressed wife, by letter, directed to "Union Mills, Fluvanna county, Virginia, " or by publication in some paper.

Shirts and Collars made to order in good style and warranted to fit. The subscriber is confident he can please, and solicits order.
Persons must furnish their own goods.
Call at my residence, on Fourth street, between Clay and Leigh.

For Sale, a large and beautiful Mirror--eighty-eight by thirty-four--richly- ornamented frame and heavy plate.
For price, inquire as above.

div3.head:
Office Richmond and Petersburg Railroad Co.,
Richmond, Virginia, November 10, 1864.
div3.p: Notice.--The annual meeting of the Stockholders of this Company will be held at their office, in this city, on Tuesday, the 29th instant, at 11 o'clock A. M.
Ladies' Straw Hats, latest style, kept always on hand.
Hats made to order at the shortest notice.
Dyeing and Pressing done to order.
A lot of Varnish, suitable for varnishing straw hats, for sale at
div3.closer: No. 75 Main street. no 12--1t*

div3.head: Notice to Farmers and Merchants.--New Molasses Barrels, Flour Barrels, Liquor Barrels and Kegs for Sale.
div3.p: --I can furnish the above in any quantity, and all of the best quality, and delivered in any part of the city without cost of drayage.
div3.closer:
William T. Trueman,
No. 86 Main street. no 11--1m

div3.p: Bouis & Sanderson, Commission Merchants, No. 80 Main street. One of the partners being exempted from all military duty, we can therefore give personal attention to sales of all kinds of merchandise and supplies generally.
This will Forewarn all persons from crediting my daughter, Fanny N. Harris, who is of unsound mind, as I will not be responsible for any debts she may contract.
div3.closer:
Lucy R. Larris.
Ashland, November 8th, 1864. no 12--2t*

div3.head: For Sale or Exchange.
div3.p: --I have a No. I Coal Cart to sell, or will exchange it, on reasonable terms, for a farm cart.

Stolen from the stable of William Haines, on Franklin, between Sixteenth and Seventeenth streets, one Bay Mare Mule, nine years old; the hoof of the right hind foot a little twisted out, the right fore hoof a little broken on the too, and slight symptom of spavin on the left hind knee.
I will pay a reward of two Hundred Dollars for her delivery to Mr. William Smither, on Franklin street, a short distance below the Market.

div3.head: Horse Stolen.--five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen from my stable, corner of Thirty-second and N. streets, Church Hill, on Friday night, the 11th instant, a small Black Mare; nearly or quite blind — may see a little out of the right eye; small legs, and a harness scar on her back.
I have reason to believe she has gone to the Twenty-fourth Virginia cavalry.
A reward of five hundred dollars will be given for the conviction of the thief and recovery of the mare, or one hundred dollars for the mare alone.

Strayed from my quarters, on Thursday, 8th instant, near the Hewlett House, a Black Mare, about fifteen and a half hands high; blind in left eye, in good condition, with her two hind feet white and a white star in her forehead.
Any information concerning her will be thankfully received by the undersigned.

closer.signed: First Lieutenant Engineers, Headquarters Pickett's division.

div3.p: Lost, in the First Market house, or on Franklin street, near Eighteenth, one Cap Box, containing two $20 and one $10 Confederate notes; also, seventy-five cents in silver and one fifty-cent (greenback) note, and my exemption pass for thirty days, and my pass given by my owner — the property of a slave boy. Any person having found it will be rewarded with half the money on leaving it at the Dispatch office.

Stolen from me a small, compact, Brown Mare Mule, about seven years old; clean limbs; fail bobbed and mane roached.--No other marks.
I will pay a satisfactory toward for her or for information leading to her recovery.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--A poor Bay Horse, ten years old, having sores on shoulders and rump, followed the carts of R. H. Allen, city a avenger, from the yard of Exchange Hotel last Tuesday evening. He was seen following in the direction of Manchester.
Fifty Dollars will be paid for information leading to his recovery.
div3.closer:
G. H. McMASTER,
Superintendent South Carolina Soldiers' Home. no 14--3t*

div3.head: Estrays.
div3.p: --Came to my house, yesterday evening, twelve Sheep and one Black Heifer, with no marks, which the owner can get by paying for this advertisement.
div3.closer: F. C. Brauer, Union Hill. no 14--3t*

div3.p:
Lost, about six weeks ago, my Free Papers.
A reward of will be paid for their recovery.

Lost, somewhere between my farm, on the New road, and Gamble's Hill, a Book entitled "the Mire Expedition," with the "compliments of the author to G. P. R. James" written on the fly leaf.
A suitable reward will be given the finder if left at this office.

Stolen from a residence in Locust Alley a small Box, containing Saddlers' Tools.
A liberal reward will be paid for their return to the Dispatch office.

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen, on the night of the 9th of November, between the New Richmond Theatre and the Central Depot (Broad street), one open-face Silver Watch, Johnson's patent lover, Liverpool.
As well as recollected, No. 1, 171, with a ladies'gold guard chain attached, with a slide and snake head hook.
Please leave it at the Dispatch office.
No questions will be asked.

div3.head: One Hundred and fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, about the 4th of October, a pair of Gold Spectacles, medium-size rims.
The finder will receive one hundred and fifty dollars reward by leaving them at the Dispatch office.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Lost, on the 3d of October, on the road leading from Mechanicsville to the Old Church, Hanover county, a Certificate for A Four Per Cent. Confederate Bond, $200. The above reward will be paid on delivery to this office or to Dr. J. G. Lumpkin, Mechanicsville.

Lost, certificates of Confederate States Eight Per Cent. Stock, in my name: No. 1, 164, for one hundred dollars, due January 1881; and No. 167, for one hundred dollars, due January, 1876.
The finder will please deliver them to Messrs. Lancaster & Co. or to myself.
div3.closer:
Mrs. Sally E. Walker,
Coalfield, Virginia. oc 22--1aw6w

div3.p:
Lost, a Confederate Four Per Cent. Certificate for five Hundred Dollars, issued by Lancaster & Co., depositaries, No. 2,318; dated March 31, 1864.
The finder will please deliver it to Lancaster & Co., or to the undersigned.

Lost, Confederate Four Per Cent. Certificate, No. 1, 862, for six Hundred Dollars, issued by Lawson Nunnally, in my name, dated March 30th, 1864.
The finder will please deliver it to Mr. J. G. Chenery or the subscriber.

Lost, on Thursday, between Chimborazo Hospital and my residence in Slabtown, my Pocket-Book, containing some silver money and my free papers.
The finder will be liberally rewarded by leaving them at the Dispatch office.
div3.closer:
Lucinda Daly,
free woman of color. no 12--2t*

div3.p:
Lost, my Retired Papers.
The finder will receive a liberal reward if they are left at the store of George W. Cottrell, No. 306 Broad street, or sent to me through the post-office.

div3.head:
Headquarters Eighteenth Va. Battalion,
Fort Gilmer, November 9, 1864.
div3.p:
Estray.--Taken up by the pickets in front of Fort Gilmer, on the 8th instant, a medium- sized Bay Horse; paces tolerably well under the saddle.
The owner is requested to come forward, prove property, and take him away.
div3.closer:
S. W. Cobb, Assistant Quartermaster,
Eighteenth Virginia battalion. no 10--10t*

div3.p:
Lost, a Breastpin, set in Etruscan gold, circular in form, with a star of small diamonds in the centre.
As the pin was broken off, it may be sent to a jeweller's to be mended.
A liberal reward will be paid for any information leading to its recovery if left at the store of E. H. Monteiro, Main street.

div3.head:
Richmond and Danville Railroad Company,
November 12, 1864.
div3.p: Stockholders' meeting.--The next annual meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company will be held in this city on Wednesday, December 12, 1864, at 12 o'clock M., at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company.

div3.head: Masonic Notice.
div3.p: --The members of Richmond Lodge, No. 10, are hereby summoned to attend a called meeting on this (Monday) Evening at 6 o'clock.
div3.closer:
By order of the W. M.
James E. Riddick, Secretary.
November 14, A. L. 5864, A. D. 1864. no 14--1t

div3.head: Millinery.
div3.p:
--Just received, an elegant assortment of Bonnets and Millinery Goods, to which the special attention of the ladies is invited.
I have also on hand a superior stock of goods for Bonnet-making, and invite a call from all ladies who wish to be their own milliners.
div3.closer:
Madame Demelman,
No. 218 Broad street. no 14--8t*

div3.head: To the Potomac.
div3.p: --Parties wishing to go through the lines to the Potomac river can be accommodated with comfortable Conveyance, on reasonable terms, at my stables, on Eighteenth street, between Franklin and Grace. Parties must be provided with proper passports.

div3.head: Piano Tuning.
div3.p: --Pianos Tuned and Repaired in the city and country.--Apply to
div3.closer:
F. A. Nervheiser,
on Twenty-fifth street,
third door south of Leigh Street Church. no 14--3t*

div3.p:
For Sale, a large Gold chain, suitable for a lady or gentleman.
Also, wanted to buy, a Light Rockaway.
Apply to
div3.closer:
B. J. Johnson,
Cary street, between Thirteenth and Virginia. no 14--1t*

div3.head: Special Notice.
div3.p: --Owners of Slaves hired at Chimborazo Hospital, second division, are requested to call on me immediately and collect the amount due to the 1st of November.
div3.closer: G. L. Gates, Hospital Steward. no 14--3t*

div3.p:
For Sale, a No. 1 Blacksmith, young and likely.
For particulars, inquire of J. E. Laughton, Basin bank, between Eighth and Ninth streets.

For Sale, fifteen hundred pounds of Pork.
Wanted, three Irish Laborers.
div3.closer:
Burruss, Garrett & Co.,
corner Franklin and Governor streets. no 14--2t*

div3.head: Blackberry Wine.
div3.p: --Two barrels Blackberry Wine, two years old, for sale by
div3.closer:
Geo. A. Weed,
Grocer, No. 50 Main street. no 14--1t*

div3.head: Richmond Theatre,
div3.p: Corner Seventh and Broad streets.
Stage Manager...E. R. Dalton.

Monday Evening, November 14, 1864, first presentation of the great French Historical
Play, in four parts, entitled.
the man in the Iron Mask,
with
Miss Katie Estelle,
Miss Jennie Powell, and
Messrs. J. S. Charles,
J. Wells,
C. T. Nelson,
H. Guion,
R. J. Brown,
E. Banker,
R. Darrell,
and
Edmond R. Dalton,
in Cast.
Fancy Dance...Miss Mary Partington.

Ballad...H. Allen.
To conclude with the laughable afterpiece of
the Widow's Victim,
in which the popular young Comedian,
C. W. Talbott,
will appear as
Jerry Clip,
with imitations of celebrated actors.
Miss Sallie Partington as
Jane Chatterley.
Doors open at quarter to 7 o'clock; performance commencing at 7½ o'clock.

div3.head: Richmond Varieties,
div3.p: Franklin street, next to the Exchange Hotel.
open every night this Week.

Palace of Fun Crowded Nightly with
the Fashion of the city.
Olio Opera Troupe and Brass Band.
Sixteen Star Performers
appear in New Melodies, Sayings, Burlesques,
Operas, Farces, &c., &c.,
assisted by Miss Inez Floyd, the charming Cantatrice, and Miss Carrie Bentley,
the fascinating Danseuse.
Immense Bill to-night.

div3.head:
A grand ball will be given
at the
New Market Hall,
div3.p:
Corner of Sixth and Marshall Streets,
On Monday Evening, November 14th, 1864.
A pleasant time will be assured to all who may attend.
Music by Professor Tremer's Cotillon Band.
Manager — G. E. Delarue.
Admission, for a gentleman and ladies, $5.

div3.head:
Misses Partington's
Dancing Academy,

p.hi: On Broad street, between Sixth and Seventh.

div3.p: Classes.--On Thursdays and Saturdays from 3 to 5 P. M.
For further particulars, call at their residence, on Leigh street, between Adams and Foushee.
No gentlemen taken.

For Rent, in one of the most desirable locations in the city, two large comfortably-furnished Chambers, a Basement, Dining-Room, part of a Kitchen, and a Coal-House, suitable for a mess of gentlemen.
The rooms can be rented separately.
Possession given on the 25th of this month.
References required.
Address, with full name, through the Dispatch office, "J. E. F. "

For Sale or Rent, one of the most desirable Residences in the city of Richmond, within two minutes walk of the capitol, containing fifteen rooms; gas in each room; bath-room, with all modern conveniences.
The house is furnished from garret to cellar.
It will be sold or rented with or without furniture.
Address "J. S.," at this office.

For Rent, a most excellent Farm of seventy acres, on the Williamsburg turnpike, only two miles from Richmond.
The buildings are desirable.
For terms, &c., apply to
div3.closer:
J. J. White, First Auditor's Office,
Treasury Department, Confederate States. no 14--3t*

div3.p: For Rent, a compact little Farm of two hundred acres, with double log house and other necessary out-buildings, one and a half mile from Kilby's station.
Terms: One-fourth of the crop.
div3.closer:
E. M. Tomkies, Ashland post-office,
Hanover county, Virginia. no 12--3t*

div3.p: Two Unfurnished rooms for Rent, on Duval street, third house from Second.
For Rent, a Neatly-Furnished Room, with servant's attention, suitable for a single gentleman, on Fourth, between Cary and Canal streets, second door from Cary.

For Rent, three rooms, over Miles & Brother's store, on Thirteenth street. They can be rented separately or all together.
Inquire of

For Rent, a very desirable Brick House, near the upper end of Clay street. The house contains six rooms, and good kitchen with two rooms, and water convenient.
For terms, apply to William Bennett, at the Richmond and Danville Railroad shop, in Manchester, or at his residence, on the Westham plankroad, near the Westham House.

For Rent, a good Chamber, with use of dining-room and kitchen, suited to a gentleman and wire, furnished or unfurnished, as preferred.
Apply on the premises, corner of Twenty-eighth and O streets.
Store for Rent.--That large and commodious Store, No. 114 Main street. For particulars, inquire at No. 169 Main street.
div3.closer: Hebener & Co. no 11--3t

div3.p:
For Rent, comfortable Furnished rooms, suitable for a small family, or gentlemen, and use of the kitchen.
Apply on Fifth street, second door from Clay, south side.

I will Rent out, or Cultivate on shares, the next year, one hundred and fifty acres or less of very good Corn Land, on the most liberal terms.
A small, but comfortable, house, garden, patch ground, and fuel for a small family, will be furnished without charge, if desired Address the subscriber, Hanover Courthouse post-office.

div3.head: Three Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, about two weeks since, my Servant Woman, Bettie.
She is of dark complexion, about six feet tall and very stout — but few women are as tall and stout.
She is somewhere in the city, I suppose cooking and washing for some persons by the day on a false pass.

Ran away, on the morning of the 10th instant, my cook, Susan.
She is of medium size, bushy hair; has lost one front tooth, and has a slight limp in her walk; light gingerbread color.
I will give $100 for her apprehension if caught in the corporation, or $500 if outside.
div3.closer: Juan Pizzini, 128 Main street. no 11--ts

div3.p:
Two Hundred Dollars reward for the apprehension and delivery to Dickinson & Hill, of Richmond, of my negro man Jack.
I purchased him of Lee & Bowman, last September.
He was formerly owned by Mrs. Mary Turner, of Petersburg.
Jack is about fifty years old; dark color; full suit of hair and whiskers, quite grey; six feet high; weighs one hundred and fifty.
I gave him permission to visit Petersburg last month, but he never returned, and is doubtless there yet.

div3.head: Five Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, about the 26th instant, a Negro Boy, named John.
He is about five feet five or six inches high; black; about twenty years old; quick spoken; was raised by the Rev. Mr. Trice, of Caroline county; he was dressed in a blue suit of clothes.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and delivery to Messrs. S. N. Davis & Co., of Richmond, or for his confinement in any jail so that I get him again.

div3.head: Three Hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, about six or seven weeks ago, my negro, Ben. Said boy was purchased at the auction house of Messrs. Lee & Bowman, Franklin street, Richmond, and was sold by Dr. Ming, of Petersburg.
He said he was hired to Mrs. Magill, at the Theatre, previous to his sale.
His age is nineteen or twenty; well built; with small head; five feet eight or nine inches in height.
He is no doubt lurking about Richmond or Petersburg.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to Messrs. Lee & Bowman, Franklin street.
div3.closer:
J. B. Pace,
Danville, Virginia. oc 20--1m*

div3.p: Found, a Sum of money, which the owner can get by applying at the corner of Eight and Main streets.

div3.head: Receiver's Sale of Four Hundred and Twenty-Four Acres of Land in the county of Henrico, near the Springfield Pits, about ten miles from Richmond.
div3.p:
--In pursuance of a decree of the District Court of the Confederate States of America for the Eastern District of Virginia, pronounced on the 12th day of August, 1864, in suit therein pending of the Confederate States against William J. Shepherdson, I shall, on the 23d day of November, 1864, proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, at 12 o'clock M., for cash, payable in Confederate States treasury notes of the new issue, the Tract of Land and its appurtenances in the proceeding in said suit mentioned, containing Four Hundred and Twenty- Four Acres, lying and being in the county of Henrico, now occupied by T. C. Leake, and known as the "Alfred Winston Tract," adjoining the Springfield Coal Mine tract, and late the property of David M. Tallmadge, an alien enemy.
The meter and boundaries of this land are particularly described in the deed conveying it to said Tallmadge, a copy of which will be exhibited at the sale.
div3.closer:
Henry L. Brooke,
Receiver of District No. 3.
Sale conducted by Grubbs & Williams, Auctioneers. no 11--tds

div3.head: Receiver's Sale of Monticello and Buck Island Estates, and other Valuable property.
div3.p: --In pursuance of a decree of the District Court of the Confederate States of America for the Eastern District of Virginia pronounced on the 27th day of September, 1864, in the case of the Confederate States against George Carr and Joel N. Wheeler, I shall sell, on the 17th day of November, at public auction, on the premises, for cash, in Confederate Treasury notes of the new issue, the following real and personal estate, late the property of Captain U. P. Levy, deceased, an alien enemy:

list.item:
1.
Monticello, a tract of two hundred and eighteen acres of land, in the county of Albemarle, in the State of Virginia, about two miles from the town of Charlottesville, with all the buildings thereon, consisting of a large and commodious brick dwelling-house, with a variety of out-buildings, planned and built by Mr. Jefferson, who owned it and resided there at the time of his death.

2. Buck Island, a tract of nine hundred and sixty-one acres, about three miles distant from Monticello, and about the same distance from the Rivanna canal.
This was once the property of James Monroe, and was by him conveyed to the Bank of the United States, by whom it was conveyed to the said U. P. Levy by deed of record in the Clerk's Office of the County Court of Albemarle.
Much of this land is arable and of good quality, and the rest is heavily timbered with pine, &c., suitable for ship-building.

3. After the sale of the real estate, there will be sold at the same time, and on the same terms, nineteen Negro Slaves, a variety of Household Furniture, Farming Utensils, Horses, Cattle, Hogs, Sheep, &c.

div3.p: The sale will be conducted by D. M. Pattie, Deputy Marshal, who resides in Charlottesville, and will show the property at any time before the sale to any one who may desire to purchase it.
div3.closer:
Henry L. Brooke,
River for District No. 3. no 2--tds

div3.head: Sale of Negroes, crop, stock and Plantation Utensils at public Auction.
div3.p: --Will be sold, on Monday, November 14th, 1864, at Wardsfork, two miles from Charlotte Court-House, thirty-three Negroes, including some good mechanics; twenty-five head Cattle; seventy Sheep; sixty-one Hogs; eleven Horses and Mules; seventeen stacks Fodder; thirty stacks Oats; about two hundred and fifty barrels of Corn; Plantation Utensils; Kitchen Furniture; also, one Carriage and Buggy.
Terms: Credit of six months except for sums of one hundred dollars and less; purchaser giving bend with approved security, bearing interest from date.
div3.closer:
Richard V. Gaines,
Robert H. Gaines,
Executors of R. I. Gaines, deceased.
Whig and Examiner copy. no 1--12t

div3.head: Paper Mill and Wood Land at Auction.

div4.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on Thursday, December 1st, at the Blue Ridge Hotel, in Botetourt county, on the macadamized road, five miles from Fincastle, a Paper Mill, located one mile from the hotel, and a Tract of Valuable Wood Land, three miles distant from the mill.
The mill is in good order, with excellent machinery, but little worn — indeed, as good as new. --The establishment is supplied with a superabundance of clear water, for washing rags, and the right to make lime for its purposes from an adjoining quarry.
Sale to take place at 12 o'clock, and terms cash.

N. B.--This valuable property may be Purchased Privately if early application is made.
If thus sold, prompt notice will be given of the fact.

div3.head: Clerk Wanted.
div3.p: --Any competent man of character, who writes rapidly and well, is entirely exempt from military duty, and understands Book-keeping, and who can devote his whole time to his employer, may hear of a Situation where advancement will follow merit by addressing "Post-office Box No. 824" in hand-writing of the applicant.
None need apply who seek temporary employment only, or fall short of the above conditions.

Wanted to Purchase, a Handsome Diamond Ring, (cluster,) for which a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Burruss, Garrett & Co.,
corner of Franklin and Governor streets. no 14--2t*

div3.head: Wanted to Purchase a Servant.
div3.p: --I wish to purchase, between now and Christmas, a first-rate Cook, Washer and Ironer; one that can be well recommended; I want no other.

Wanted to Rent, a small Furnished Room.
Terms must be moderate.
Please address, immediately, stating particulars, "J. H. H.," Dispatch office.

Wanted, a Governess, to take charge of six pupils, in a private family residing in Charleston District, South Carolina.
She will be expected to teach the higher branches of English, with French and Music.
Terms: $100 per year; board, lights, fuel, and washing being furnished.
Address Mrs. White, post-office box 1,150, Richmond, Va.

Wanted to Rent, a Furnished House, of not less than five or six rooms, kitchen and other conveniences, in any eligible location on Shockoe Hill or other western portion of the city.
Immediate possession desired, and the best references given if necessary.
Address "B., " box No. 1,433, Richmond post-office.

Wanted to sell, the Lease of the Brick House, in Sidney, on the corner of Pine street and the Westham plankroad.
It has three years and four months to run. Inquire of
div3.closer:
John A. Temple,
near Camp Winder. no 12--2t*

div3.p:
Wanted, a smart colored Girl, to do Light Housework in a small family.
Apply on Franklin street, north side, one door below Fifth.
Wanted, two good Shoemakers, for which a good price will be paid by applying at the store of Carter & Talley, Franklin street, between Seventeenth and Eighteenth, Richmond, Virginia.

Wanted, a good Melodeon.
Address "Box 837," Richmond post-office.

Wanted, as Book-Keeper, and to make himself generally useful in a store on Main street, a gentleman of first-rate qualifications, undoubted references, and exempt from military service.
Address "Post-office Box No. 179."

Wanted, a Male Teacher, to go to the county of Buckingham, Va., to teach in a private family.
He must be well qualified to teach French, Latin and Mathematics.
Address
div3.closer:
Charles Y. Morriss,
Richmond, Virginia. no 11--ts

div3.p:
Wanted, a good Cook, &c., two Shoemakers, two Boys and four Girls.
Address "M., " Dispatch office.

Wanted to Rent, a Piano, of which good care will be taken.
Address "Box 1,605," Richmond post-office.

Wanted, a Governess, to teach five girls; capable of teaching Music, Latin, French and Mathematics.
Board and a salary of $1,000 offered.
Address "William W. Read," Charlotte Courthouse, Virginia.

div3.head: Book-Keeper Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted to employ a competent Book-Keeper; would prefer one who could give his entire time to business, but would treat with one for a portion of his time.
Apply at No. 68 Main street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman and wife wish to obtain an Unfurnished Room in a retired part of the city.
The highest price will be paid.
Address box "H.," Dispatch office.
Superior Green Tea,
Superior Black Tea.,

family-Cured Bacon, warranted of the best quality,
this day receiving and for sale at
div3.closer:
L. Yerby's,
No. 5 Twelfth street, south of Main. no 12--6t*

div3.p: Steam Engine, of twenty-horse power, and Boiler, for sale.
div3.closer: B. Wendenburg & Co. no 11--6t*

div3.p:
Four Per Cent. Bonds.
15,000 Four Per Cent. Bonds for sale by

div3.head:
By Redwood, Phillips & Co., Auctioneers,
(no. 54 Main street.)
div3.p: We will sell, at our Store, No. 54 Main street, on Monday, the 14th instant, at 10 o'clock, an assortment of
Household and Kitchen Furniture, Stoves, &c.
2 barrels of Rice,
1 barrel of Flour,
Showcase, Clothing, &c.
div3.closer:
Redwood, Phillips & Co.,
Auctioneers. no 12

div3.head: By E. S. Pleasants, Auctioneer.

div3.head: Likely Free Negro Boy for Sale at Auction.
div3.p: --In pursuance of an order of the Hustings Court of the city of Richmond, I will sell, on Monday next, the 14th instant (that being court day), in front of the City Hall, at 10½ o'clock, to the highest bidder, for cash, a very likely Free Negro Boy, named Thomas White, convicted by said court of grand larceny and ordered to be sold into absolute slavery.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, November 3, 1864.
div3.p: Circular.--It being decided that four per cent. certificates, and the bonds issued therefore, are receivable in payment of the tax on coin, moneys held abroad, bills of exchange and foreign credits, persons who have paid these taxes in new issue are entitled to the return of the notes.

The Treasurer, Assistant Treasurers and Pay Depositaries who have received the deposits of tax collectors are authorized, in such cases, to refund the notes and receive in lieu thereof an equal amount of four per cent. certificates, or bonds, upon the demand of the State Tax Collector.
And the bonds or certificates to be exchanged shall be endorsed as follows: "I certify that the within (or attached) certificate was received from -- -- in lieu of so much tax erroneously collected from him in currency of the new issue, and that the same has been exchanged for new issue to reimburse him;" and signed by the State Tax Collector.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, October 12, 1864.
div3.p: Non-Taxable Bonds, five Hundred-Million Loan.--Sale Continued.--Numerous applications having been made for bonds at the established price of one hundred and thirty-five dollars and interest, under circumstances that entitle them to favorable consideration, it has been determined to continue the sale at the above price until further notice.
Agents for the sale of these Bonds are instructed to act in accordance with this order; and the attention of disbursing officers of the Government is particularly called to it.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, August 8, 1864.
div3.p:
Certificates of Indebtedness Bearing six Per Cent. Per Annum interest and Free from Taxation. --By the fourteenth section of the act to reduce the currency, approved February 17, 1864, the Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to issue the above certificates, payable two years after the ratification of a treaty of peace with the United States.
They cannot be sold, but are only to be issued to such creditors of the Government as are willing to receive the same in payment of their demands.
They must also be given at par, though free from taxation.

The attention of purchasing agents and disbursing officers of the Government is called to this class of public securities as offering peculiar advantages to those from whom the supplies of the Government are bought; and to facilitate the use of them, checks drawn by disbursing officers upon the depositaries holding these funds, and marked across the face "payable in certificates of indebtedness," will be paid in conformity therewith.
Depositaries are hereby authorized and required to comply with this regulation, and to make application to the Register for supplies of certificates as required.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America.
div3.p:
Loans on the Security of the five Hundred Million six Per Cent. Non-Taxable Bonds, under the Seventh section of the Currency law.--Deposits on call will be received by the Treasurer in this city, Assistant Treasurers at Charleston and Mobile, and the Depositaries at Wilmington, Raleigh, Columbia, Augusta, Savannah and Montgomery, and certificates will be issued for the same, bearing interest at the rate of four per cent. per annum, and secured by the hypothecation of an amount of the above bonds equal to the sum of these loans.
The bonds to be set apart by the Treasurer, and the proceeds, when sold, applied exclusively to the payment of the said certificates.

The security and convenience afforded to banks and other corporations, and to the public generally, by this mode of temporary investment, and the effect of the measure, if generally adopted, in keeping the currency within moderate bounds, it is hoped will commend it to the favorable consideration of the community and secure their prompt co-operation in carrying it into effect.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, Va, August 26, 1864.
div3.p: Regulations for Carrying into Effect the Act of Congress Approved June 13, 1864, Authorizing Owners of Registered Eight Per Cent. Bonds, issued under the Provisions of the Act Approved may 16, 1861, to Exchange the same for Coupon Bonds.--Parties owning registered eight per cent. bonds under the act of May 16, 1861, desiring to exchange them for coupon bonds, will assign them, in the manner pointed out in the printed endorsement on the back of the certificate, to the "Confederate States of America, in exchange for coupon bonds, " and cause them to be presented to the Register of the Treasury Department, who will thereupon, in compliance with the provisions of the act of June 13, 1864, issue coupon bonds for the amount specified in the registered bonds so assigned.

div3.head:
Treasury Department,
Confederate States of America,
Richmond, July 28, 1864.
div3.p:
Taxed Treasury notes.--In order to promote, as far as practicable, the early liquidation by the Treasury of the Outstanding Taxed notes, the Treasurer, Assistant Treasurer, and Pay Depositaries in the different States, are hereby authorized to receive the said notes, except the $100 notes, at 66 per centum, on deposit, issuing for same certificates of loan, upon hypothecation of non-taxable bonds.
The said certificates to be payable on demand after the expiration of ninety days.
And all agents for the sale of the above bonds are hereby authorized to receive the taxed notes, with the exception above named, in payment of bonds when sold, at the rate of 66 per centum.

div3.head:
Richmond and Danville Railroad,
Richmond, October 1, 1864.
div3.p:
Notice.--The Evening Passenger Train on the Richmond and Danville railroad will be Discontinued until further notice — the transportation of Government freight requiring almost the entire capacity of the road.
The Morning Passenger Train will run as usual.

div3.head: Three very Valuable Brick Tenements, on Main street, and large Lumber-House, on Seventeenth, between Main and Cary streets, with large vacant Lot in rear, for Sale Privately.
div3.p:
--We offer for sale, privately, the three large Brick Tenements, on Main street, occupied respectively by William J. Harwood, L. Letterman and Mr. Jacobs.
These are business houses, and have the advantage of being residences at the same time, and have back buildings suited for kitchens, affording ample servants' accommodations.
The Lumber-House or Factory is large, substantially built, and in pretty good repair, with a large Lot in rear, extending back to Shockoe creek, sufficient for the erection of one or more large warehouses or buildings of other descriptions.
This is all very valuable property, such as is now very rarely offered in the market.
For terms, &c., apply to

div3.head: Valuable property in the town of Maysville, Buckingham Courthouse, for Sale.
div3.p:
--The tavern property situated as above is offered at private sale.
The improvements are, a large brick building, with thirteen rooms: a brick office, with two rooms; three framed offices, with four rooms; large stable, kitchen, cabins, smoke-house, ice-house and other buildings.
There are six acres in the lot, including a large garden, and twenty acres of wood land within convenient distance, say one and a half miles. Immediate possession given.

div3.head: Saw and Grist Mill for Sale.
div3.p:
At the request of Dr. D. C. Winfree, we offer for sale his Saw and Grist Mill, in Chesterfield county, situated on Falling creek; (a never falling stream,) six miles from Manchester, with four acres of Land attached.
They are in good running order, having been put in complete repair during the present year.
The water-power is exceedingly valuable, independent of the mills new on it. Timber for sawing can be purchased within about a mile of the mills.
Well managed, they can be rendered exceedingly valuable.
Apply to

For Sale, Privately, A Farm of three Hundred and Twenty Acres of Land: two-thirds cleared, the remainder in woods.
There are upon the farm two good dwelling-houses and the usual out-houses. --The farm is situated immediately at and around Malone's crossing, on the Weldon railroad, twelve miles south of Petersburg.
Also, a Farm of seventy-five Acres, in the county of Buckingham, six miles south of Howardsville, on the Courthouse road, near Glenmore: ten acres cleared; remainder in original forest.
Improvements, a comfortable log cabin, kitchen, meat-house, corn-crib, poultry-house, stable, &c., &c. Being in the service of our country, and having no opportunity to attend to these farms, I have determined to sell them, and only ask the low price of Eighty (80) Dollars Per Acre in Confederate States money, new issue, for the three hundred and twenty acre tract; and for the seventy-five acre tract, one Hundred (100) Dollars Per Acre.
For particulars and description, apply to or address a once.
John Dollins, company F, Tenth Virginia cavalry, Chambliss's brigade, W. H. F. Lee's division, Army Northern Virginia, via Richmond, Virginia.

div3.head:
Proclamation
Appointing a day for public worship.
div3.p: It is meet that the people of the Confederate States should, from time to time, assemble to acknowledge their dependence on Almighty God, to render devout thanks for His manifold blessings, to worship His Holy name, to bend in prayer at His footstool, and to accept with reverent submission the chastening of His All-wise and All-merciful Providence.

Let us, then, in temples and in fields, unite our voices in recognizing, with adoring gratitude, the manifestations of His protecting care in the many signal victories with which our arms have been crowned, in the fruitfulness with which our land has been blessed, and in the unimpaired energy and fortitude with which He has inspired our hearts and strengthened our arms in resistance to the iniquitous designs of our enemies.

And let us not forget that, while graciously vouchsafing to us His protection, our sins have merited and received grievous chastisement; that many of our best and bravest have fallen in battle; that many others are still held in foreign prisons; that large districts of our country have been devastated with savage ferocity — the peaceful homes destroyed and helpless women and children driven away in destitution; and that with fiendish malignity the passions of a servile race have been excited by our foes into the commission of atrocities from which death is a welcome escape.

Now, therefore, I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do issue this my proclamation, setting apart Wednesday, the sixteenth day of November next, as a day to be specially devoted to the worship of Almighty God; and I do invite and invoke all the people of these Confederate States to assemble on the day aforesaid, in their respective places of public worship, there to unite in prayer to our Heavenly Father, that He bestow His favor upon us; that He extend over us the protection of His almighty arm; that He sanctify His chastisement to our improvement, so that we may turn away from evil paths and walk righteously in His sight; that He restore peace to our beloved country, healing its bleeding wounds, and securing to us the continued enjoyment of our right of self-government and independence; and that He graciously hearken to us, while we ascribe to Him the power and glory of our deliverance.
Given under my hand and the seal of the Confederate States, at Richmond, this twenty-sixth day of October, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-four.
div3.closer:
Jefferson Davis.
By the President:
J. P. Benjamin, Secretary of State. [oc 27--td]

div3.head:
State of Virginia, Executive Department,
Richmond, November 1, 1864.
div3.p: A Proclamation.--The General Assembly of this Commonwealth having, on the 27th of February last, adopted a joint resolution requesting to be convened on the first Wednesday in December next; and a majority of that body having, in writing, on the 10th day of March last, also asked that they shall be re-assembled at the time aforesaid, therefore

I. William Smith, Governor of the Commonwealth, in deference to wishes thus expressed, do hereby announce by this, my proclamation, to the Senators and Delegates of the General Assembly of this Commonwealth, that they are required to convene at the Capitol, in the city of Richmond, on the First Wednesday in December next, at 12 o'clock M., then and there to take into consideration the condition of public affairs and to enact such laws as they may deem necessary and proper.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this first day of November, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, and in the eighty ninth year of the Commonwealth.
div3.closer:
William Smith.
Teste: George W. Munford,
Secretary of the Commonwealth. no 3--1aw3w

div3.head:
Headquarters Virginia Military Institute,
Lexington, Virginia, November 8, 1864.

list.head: Special orders no. 23.
list.item:
I. The regular Academic Exercises of the Institution will be resumed at the Alms-House, Richmond, on the 1st of December.
All Professors, Assistant Professors, Officers and Cadres, except such as may receive other orders, will promptly report for duty at the time and place designated.

II.
As unavoidable causes have delayed the resumption of duties, the deposit called for by the quarterly circular will be reduced to $1,500, and may be placed to the credit of the Treasurer of the Virginia Military Institute in the Farmers' Bank of Virginia on or before the 1st of December.
When supplies are deposited by a Cadet, the money deposit will be diminished by the value of these supplies, estimated by schedule rates.
Should the deposits now called for be insufficient to meet current expenses, due notice will be given.

div3.closer:
By command of
Major-General F. H. Smith.
J. H. Morrison, Acting Adjutant Virginia Military Institute. no 12--2awtDet

div3.head:
State of Virginia, Executive Department,
Richmond, November 4, 1864.
div3.p: A Proclamation.--Whereas, a vacancy has occurred in the General Assembly of this Commonwealth by the resignation of S. W. Thomas, the member of the House of Delegates from the county of Warren; therefore,

I. William Smith, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, do hereby proclaim and make known that an election will be held in said county, at the places prescribed by law, to supply the vacancy aforesaid, on the First Thursday in December next.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the lesser seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 4th day of November, 1864, and in the eighty-ninth year of the Commonwealth.
div3.closer:
William Smith.
Teste: George W. Munford,
Secretary of the Commonwealth. no 7--tde
